module.p:
tuar is a masculine simple common noun, with genitive singular form tuair, and plural form tuaran. Dictionary senses are –
[original] augury, portent, presage, omen, foreboding, auspice (cf. tuarach adj. portentous), derived from Old Gaelic túar sign, omen, portent
[derived] appearance, look, complexion, hue, colour, mien, tint
Cha toigh leam an tuar a tha ort idir.
I don’t like your colour at all. td. 602
Bha tuar a chraicinn cho donn ris an leathar.
The complexion of his skin was as brown as leather. td. 602
faileus mun tuar
a shade upon their countenance td. 977
mar thuar na soillse
like the appearance of light td. 977
[other senses listen in Dwelly] hardship, food, cast, fear, life, forerunner, house, advantage, profit, merit, desert
gnè sam bith thuair
any kind of hardship td. 977
ìongantas mun tuar
wonder at their fear td. 977
gun teach gun tuar
without house or life td. 977

When followed by an infinitive (verbal noun), bi air thuar look (as if one is) about to / on the verge/point of ... can be used to mark a combination of evidentiality and prospective aspect –
Bha Màiri air thuar gnogadh air an doras. Mary looked (as if she were) about to knock on the door.

Examples –
intransitive verbs –
dictionaries –
Bha an teine air thuar a dhol bàs.
The fire was about to die. td. 602
Bha e air thuar faighneach dhiubh dè bha cho eibhinn mun chùis.
He was on the point of asking them what was so funny about the matter. td. 603
corpus –
Thug an nighean tarraing air a ghàirdean. “Leig leotha, ghràidh. Na cuir diù sa bith annta; chan eil ann ach gòraiche na h-aoise,” ars ise. “Gòraiche ’n donais,” ars esan, ’se ga putadh uaithe, “tha fhios agamsa glé mhath dé tha clann an à’rsair ris. Ach cuiridh mise stad air mun teid e nas fhaide.” Bha e air thuar éirigh nuair a bhuail a’ cheud rotach gaoithe an tigh.
The girl pulled at his arm. “Leave them, darling. Don’t pay any heed to them; it is just the stupidity of age,” she said. “The stupidity of evil,” he said, pushing her away, “I know very well what the children of the devil?. But I will put a stop to it before it goes any further.” He (looked as if he) was about to stand up when the first blast of wind hit the house. td. 18
An deidh bliadhnaichean san oilthaigh cha robh Daibhidh [MacLiuthair] sàsaichte leis na fhuair e de ionnsachadh. Bu mhath leis cosnadh is còmhradh a dheanamh cuide ri daoine de gach seòrsa agus suidheachadh. [...] Mu dheireadh fhuair Daibhidh smear na “dachaigh” cuide ri Rob, an seann iasgair agus obair chunabhalach cuide ri Seoc Beag ann an Cas Lannain, beagan a deas air Inbhir-àr. Fhuair e cuideachd eòlas air an Diùc, aig an robh oighreachd faisg air làimh agus air Barabal, a nighean a bha cumail taighe — na cumail caisteil — dha h-athair. Thuit e fhéin is Barabal an trom ghaol a dh’aindeoin ’s nach robh taobh sam bith aige ri “na daoine móra” agus aig deireadh na sgeulachd tha iad air thuar pòsadh.
After years at the university David [MacLure] was not satisfied with what he had learned. He wanted to work and converse with people of every kind and situation. [...] Eventually David found a kind of “home” with Rob, the old fisherman and a steady job with Wee Jock in Cas Lannain, just south of Inveraray. He also got to know the Duke, who owned an estate close by, as well as Barbara, his daughter who kept house – or kept castle – for her faher. He and Barbara fell deeply in love despite the fact that he had no truck with the “gentry” and at the end of the story, it seems as if they are about to get married. td. 377
Bha Donnchadh a’ tighinn gu tapaidh \ Ged bha e car lapach ’s an àm \ Ach thuit e air dheireadh ’na ònar \ Cha chumadh e còmh’ ris an dream \ ’S theann e ri glaodhaich dha ’n chòmhlan — \ “A chlann an Fhir Mhóir tha sibh ann; \ ’S ann tha sibh air thuar dhol ’gam fhàgail, \ Nuair thàinig am bàs orm gu teann. \ O, nach sibh a ni ’n call, \ Ma dh’fhàgas sibh mise ’s mi mall; \ Ma thuiteas mi ’n làmhan nam biastan ud \ Théid mi dha ’n t-sìorruidheachd thall.”
Duncan was coming quickly \ Though he was somewhat feeble at the time \ But he fell behind by himself \ He didn’t keep up with the people \ And he started to shout to the group – \ “You are the children of the Big Men; \ You look as if you are about to be going to leave me \ When death has come close to me. \ Oh, is it not you who will do the damage \ If you leave me while I am slow; \ If I fall into the hands of those beasts \ I will go over to eternity.” td. 42
Aig an dearbh àm, chaidh dithis eile fear air gach taobh dhìom agus rinn iad greim orm. Bha mi air thuar tionndadh is ìnnse dhaibh nach b’ urrainn dhòmhsa an crodh fhàgail an sud leotha fhéin, an uair a fhuair mi ùpag uabhasach o fhear aca. Laigh cròg mhór ghreimeil an fhir eile air mo ghualainn agus chaidh mo stiùireadh air adhart.
At the same time, another pair of men went to either side of me and took a hold of me. I was about to turn and tell them that I couldn’t leave the cattle there on their own, when I got a terrible shove from one of them. A bog clenched paw of the other man landed on my shoulder and I was led forward. td. 117 ‘look about to turn’ makes no sense in the first person
transitive verbs –
inversion –
“Cha b’ urrainn dhomh sian a dheanamh ach suidhe air an tobhtaidh mheadhoin is mi lag le tioma is struth o ' m shùilean a’ gul airson a’ bhalaich bhochd a bha sud, ge bè air bith có bu leis e . Co - dhiùbh nuair a fhuair mi seachad a’ chiad smaointinn a chuir an sealladh brònach ud orm chaidh mi sìos air mo shocair dha ’n deireadh agus gu faiceallach, mar nach bithinn airson gun goirtichinn e thog mi an ceann fliuch fuar leis an fhalt dhualach dhubh.” Stad Fearchar ann a seo agus cha robh e air thuar an còrr a ràdha.
[...] Fearchar stopped there and he didn’t look [as if he was] about to say anything else. td. 217
possessive determiners –
Mu dheireadh thall chaill i a cùrsa gu buileach, ’s cha robh fhios aice c’àite an robh i ’dol. Mar nach b’ ioghnadh, an déigh na rinn i ’dh’astar ré an latha, bha i air fàs glé sgìth agus airsneulach. Bha na h-uile rud a bh’ ann a’ dol ’na h-aghaidh, agus ged a bha deagh mhisneach aice riamh bha i nis air thuar a tréigsinn gu buileach.
Eventually, she completely lost her way, and she did not know where she was going. Unsurprisingly, after the distance she had covered during the day, she had become very tired and weary. Everything had gone against her, and although she had always had a lot of courage it seemed to be about to abandon her completely. Vol. 6 td. 240
Thàinig Ludovic air adhart agus chuir Eachann am funail gu cùramach air ais air a’ bhòrd is rug e cho sòlamaichte air làimh air ’s gu saoileadh tu gur e am ministear a bha air tadhal. [...] Bha deathach dhubh, ghrànda a’ tighinn a siobhag na lampadh, air thuar an tachdadh le droch fhàileadh.
Ludovic came forward and Hector put the funnel carefully back on the table and ?? so solemnly that you would think that it was the minister who was visiting. [...] Ugly black smoke was coming from the wick of the lamp, looking [as if it were] about to suffocate them with bad smell. td. 76
bi air thuar (a bhith) –
An ceann beagan ùine, dh’ fhàs Fear a’ Choire gu tinn. Cha robh e féin no duine eile a’ tuigsinn gu dé bha ceàrr. Thàinig lighiche an déidh lighiche g’a fhaicinn, ach a dh’aindeoin na dheanadh iad ris, bha a shlàinte a’ sìor dhol an lughad. Mu dheireadh, nuair a bha e air thuar a bhith faighinn bhàis, dé a thachair gu fortanach ach gun do thuit do thé de na bana-bhuidsichean faclan a ràdh a bhrath i fhéin agus na bha ’na comunn.
After a short while, the Corry Man became ill. Neither he nor anyone else understood what was wrong. Doctor after doctor came to see him, but no matter what they did to him, his health got ever worse. Eventually, when it looked as if he were about to die, what happened, fortunately, but that one of the witches happened to say words that betrayed her and those who were in her company. td. 353
Dh’ éirich i fhéin an uair sin agus chuir i ’n coire air ged nach robh iarraidh agam fuireach is an tì òl. Ach b’ éiginn sin a dhèanamh agus éisdeachd ri móran eile o Dhonnchadh. B’ ann mu fhear Cleveland, an Ameireaga, a bha e bruidhinn; fear a thànaig á dachaidh glé bhochd ach a bha nis air thuar a bhith Phrìomhaire air na Stàitean Aonaichte.
She got up herself then and put the kettle on even though I didn’t want to stay and drink the tea. But it was necessary to do that and to listen to much else from Duncan. It was about a Cleveland man, in America, that he was talking; a man who came from a very poor home but who now looked [as if he were] about to be President of the United States. td. 320
Cha b’ urrain do’n aireamh mhor shluaigh a chruinnich a dh’fhaicinn a’ chrochaidh gun a bhith ri caoidh ’s ri sileadh dheur an uair a chunnaic iad an sealladh bronach so; oir bha ’n t-ard-chomhairleach agus na daoine eile a bha gu bhith air an crochadh maille ris fo mhiadh agus fo mhor meas aig an t-sluagh gu leir air son cho ceart, cho fialaidh, agus cho neo-eismeileach ’s a bha iad, cha b’ ann a mhain ri sluagh Bhagdad, ach mar an ceudna ri sluagh na rioghachd gu leir. Cha robh ni sam bith a chumadh an righ air ais o chur an orduigh a thug e seachad an gniomh; agus bha beatha nan daoine cho measail ’s cho urramach ’s a bh’ anns a bhaile air thuar a bhith air a toirt air falbh.
The large number of people who gathered to see the hanging couldn’t ?? without being lamenting and flowing tears when they saw this sad sight; because the high councillor and the other men who looked as if they were about to be hanged along with him were esteemed and highly regarded by all the people for how fair, how generous, and how independent they were, not just the people of Bagdad, but likewise the people of the whole kingdom. There was nothing holding the king back from sending out the order that he passed the action; and the life of men who were so esteemed and so trusted as any in the city looked [as if it was] about to be taken away. Vol. 3 td. 49

However, air thuar (a bhith) having the appearance of (being), seeming seems to perhaps lack a prospective reading –
Cha bhiodh do bhas cho fadalach ’s cho uamhasach ’s a tha e nis air thuar a bhith.
Your death will not be as slow and horrible as it now seems it will be. td. ??
Ged a bha i air thuar a bhith air a cuartachadh le gainmhich an fhàsaich ann an dòigh no dhà bha cinnt aice gun robh Neach ann a dhèanadh faire thairis oirre.
Although she was about / appeared to be surrounded by the desert sand in a way or two td. ??
’S beag an t-iongnadh ged ’se an ‘Dying Island’ bh’ aca air sna pàipearan naidheachd. Cha robh air thuar bhith air fhàgail ann ach seann daoine is beagan chloinne. Cha robh taic aca bho ghàirdean neartmhor nan òganach.
It seemed that only old people and some children had remained there. td. ??
Ah, uill, nam biodh an fhoghluim a fhuair e agamsa, chan fhuirichinn-sa fada ’san àite-sa. Chan eil fhios am dé tha ’gan cumail ’s gun duine cloinneadh air thuar a bhith aca.
Oh well, if I had the education that he got, I would not stay long in this place. I do not know what is keeping them and it does not seem they will have any children. td. ??
Bha ’n seo am feasgar a’ tighinn, ’s bha sinn air thuar a bhith deiseil dhi ann an deagh-amm; bha seachd cairtean a’ tarraing uice.
we were about to be ready with it. td. ??
Thràigh iad fuaran nam buadh, dh’fhàg iad sluagh ann an càs, Tha ceàrnachan tuath ’s iad air thuar a bhith fàs; Tha na fàrdraichean fuar a bha uaireigin blàth, ’S chan eil àbhachd aig cluais mur eil fuaim a’ mhuir-làin.
and they are about / appear to be deserted td. ??
Ach thàinig an seo an gobha a mach o a dhìnneir, agus ghabh an cuilein leóghainn ige, agus rug e air ’na bhial air aodach, agus bhuail e stràc ris an innein, agus nuair a dh’éirich e, rug an cuilein leóghainn air agus bhuail e go taobh thall na ceàrdaich e, agus chaidh an éibh a mach go bean Mhànuis gu robh an gobha air thuar a bhith air a mharbhadh aig a’ chuilein leóghainn.
that, apparently, the blacksmith was going to be killed by the lion cub td. ??
Cha robh cabhag sam bith air fear seach fear dhiubh gu falbh o ’n bhòrd, oir bha iad air thuar a bhith ’nan dlùth cháirdean, eadar a h-uile comhradh a bh eatorra.
they appeared to be close friends? td. ??
Dh’aontaich ard-chomhairle na rioghachd gu ’n deanteadh mar a bha ’n righ a’ runachadh. An uair a chuala sluagh na rioghachd mar a bha cuisean air thuar a bhith, bha iad gu leir anabarrach toilichte; oir thuig iad gu math gu ’m biodh Beder ’na righ cho cothromach ’s a bha riamh a’ riaghladh anns an rioghachd.
as, apparently, things were about to be td. ??
Bha aca ri pailt ochd mile a dheanamh mu ’n ruigeadh iad taigh an doctair far an robh Fear a’ bhaile gus an oidhche ’chur seachad. Bha ’n oidhche air thuar a bhith gu math soilleir, oir bha àirde gealaich ann.
It seemed that the night would be clear/bright?
Bha a’ chùis seo air thuar a bhith cho annasach rithe.
Thus case appeared to be as unusual as it. td. 602
cf. Other markers of prospective aspect – gu(s), an impis, air bheul, air lunn.

bi a t[h]uar air ... look (as if one is) about to / on the verge/point of ... can be used to mark a mixture of evidentiality and prospective aspect, though mainly in older texts –
Bha a t[h]uar air Màiri gnogadh air an doras. Mary looked (as if she were) about to knock on the door.
Bha a thuar air a' bhreitheamh mo leigeil mu sgaoil.
The judge appeared likely to let me go. td. 978
Tràth bhios tuar a' dol ás air na gobhair, cha bheir iad ach buic.
When the goats are about to become extinct (senseless), they only bring forth bucks. td. 977–8
Chan eil tuar air an t-iasgach tighinn na b' fheàrr.
There is no appearance of the fishing improving. td. 977
